text: When the Philistine drew nearer to meet David, David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put his hand in his bag, took out a stone, slung it, and struck the Philistine on his forehead; the stone sank into his forehead, and he fell face down on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and a stone, striking down the Philistine and killing him; there was no sword in David’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David ran and stood over the Philistine; he grasped his sword, drew it out of its sheath, and killed him; then he cut off his head with it.
When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The troops of Israel and Judah rose up with a shout and pursued the Philistines as far as Gath and the gates of Ekron, so that the wounded Philistines fell on the way from Shaaraim as far as Gath and Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites came back from chasing the Philistines, and they plundered their camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem, but he put his armor in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw David go out against the Philistine, he said to Abner, the commander of the army, “Abner, whose son is this young man?” Abner said, “As your soul lives, O king, I do not know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Inquire whose son the young man is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On David’s return from killing the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him before Saul, with the head of the Philistine in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to him, “Whose son are you, young man?” And David answered, “I am the son of your servant Jesse the Bethlehemite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished speaking to Saul, the soul of Jonathan was bound to the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul took him that day and would not let him return to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan made a covenant with David because he loved him as his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that he was wearing and gave it to David and his armor and even his sword and his bow and his belt.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went out and was successful wherever Saul sent him; as a result, Saul set him over the army. And all the people, even the servants of Saul, approved.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were coming home, when David returned from killing the Philistine, the women came out of all the towns of Israel, singing and dancing, to meet King Saul, with tambourines, with songs of joy, and with musical instruments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the women sang to one another as they made merry,
“Saul has killed his thousands
    and David his ten thousands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was very angry, for this saying displeased him. He said, “They have ascribed to David ten thousands, and to me they have ascribed thousands; what more can he have but the kingdom?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul eyed David from that day on.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day an evil spirit from God rushed upon Saul, and he raved within his house, while David was playing the lyre, as he did day by day. Saul had his spear in his hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Saul threw the spear, for he thought, “I will pin David to the wall.” But David eluded him twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was afraid of David because the Lord was with him but had departed from Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul removed him from his presence and made him a commander of a thousand, and David marched out and came in, leading the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had success in all his undertakings, for the Lord was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw that he had great success, he stood in awe of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all Israel and Judah loved David, for it was he who marched out and came in leading them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to David, “Here is my elder daughter Merab; I will give her to you as a wife; only be valiant for me and fight the Lord’s battles.” For Saul thought, “I will not raise a hand against him; let the Philistines deal with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Who am I, and who are my kinsfolk, my father’s family in Israel, that I should be son-in-law to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But at the time when Saul’s daughter Merab should have been given to David, she was given to Adriel the Meholathite as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul’s daughter Michal loved David. Saul was told, and the thing pleased him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul thought, “Let me give her to him that she may be a snare for him and that the hand of the Philistines may be against him.” Therefore Saul said to David a second time, “You shall now be my son-in-law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul commanded his servants, “Speak to David in private and say, ‘See, the king is delighted with you, and all his servants love you; now then, become the king’s son-in-law.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul’s servants reported these words to David in private. And David said, “Does it seem to you a little thing to become the king’s son-in-law, seeing that I am a poor man and of no repute?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants of Saul told him, “This is what David said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “Thus shall you say to David, ‘The king desires no marriage present except a hundred foreskins of the Philistines, that he may be avenged on the king’s enemies.’ ” Now Saul planned to make David fall by the hand of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his servants told David these words, David was well pleased to be the king’s son-in-law. Before the time had expired,
speaker: Narrator

text: David rose and went, along with his men, and killed one hundred of the Philistines, and David brought their foreskins, which were given in full number to the king, that he might become the king’s son-in-law. Saul gave him his daughter Michal as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Saul realized that the Lord was with David and that Saul’s daughter Michal loved him,
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was still more afraid of David. So Saul was David’s enemy from that time forward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the commanders of the Philistines came out to battle, and as often as they came out, David had more success than all the servants of Saul, so that his fame became very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul spoke with his son Jonathan and with all his servants about killing David. But Saul’s son Jonathan took great delight in David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan told David, “My father Saul is trying to kill you; therefore be on guard tomorrow morning; stay in a secret place and hide yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where you are, and I will speak to my father about you; if I learn anything I will tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan spoke well of David to his father Saul, saying to him, “The king should not sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you and because his deeds have been of good service to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he took his life in his hand when he attacked the Philistine, and the Lord brought about a great victory for all Israel. You saw it and rejoiced; why then will you sin against an innocent person by killing David without cause?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul heeded the voice of Jonathan; Saul swore, “As the Lord lives, he shall not be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan called David and related all these things to him. Jonathan then brought David to Saul, and he was in his presence as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again there was war, and David went out to fight the Philistines. He launched a heavy attack on them, so that they fled before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then an evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul as he sat in his house with his spear in his hand, while David was playing music.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sought to pin David to the wall with the spear, but he eluded Saul, so that he struck the spear into the wall. David fled and escaped that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to David’s house to keep watch over him, planning to kill him in the morning. David’s wife Michal told him, “If you do not save your life tonight, tomorrow you will be killed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Michal let David down through the window; he fled away and escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Michal took an idol and laid it on the bed; she put a net of goats’ hair on its head and covered it with the clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul sent messengers to take David, she said, “He is sick.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul sent the messengers to see David for themselves. He said, “Bring him up to me in the bed, that I may kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers came in, the idol was in the bed, with the covering of goats’ hair on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Michal, “Why have you deceived me like this and let my enemy go, so that he has escaped?” Michal answered Saul, “He said to me, ‘Let me go; why should I kill you?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David fled and escaped; he came to Samuel at Ramah and told him all that Saul had done to him. He and Samuel went and settled at Naioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was told, “David is at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul sent messengers to take David. When they saw the company of the prophets in a frenzy, with Samuel standing in charge of them, the spirit of God came upon the messengers of Saul, and they also fell into a prophetic frenzy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul was told, he sent other messengers, and they also fell into a frenzy. Saul sent messengers again the third time, and they also fell into a frenzy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he himself went to Ramah. He came to the great well that is in Secu; he asked, “Where are Samuel and David?” And someone said, “They are at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went there, toward Naioth in Ramah, and the spirit of God came upon him. As he was going, he fell into a prophetic frenzy, until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He, too, stripped off his clothes, and he, too, fell into a frenzy before Samuel. He lay naked all that day and all that night. Therefore it is said, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David fled from Naioth in Ramah. He came before Jonathan and said, “What have I done? What is my guilt? And what is my sin against your father that he is trying to take my life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Far from it! You shall not die. My father does nothing either great or small without disclosing it to me, and why should my father hide this from me? Never!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David also swore, “Your father knows well that you like me, and he thinks, ‘Do not let Jonathan know this, or he will be grieved.’ But truly, as the Lord lives and as you yourself live, there is but a step between me and death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said to David, “Whatever you say, I will do for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Jonathan, “Tomorrow is the new moon, and I should not fail to sit with the king at the meal, but let me go, so that I may hide in the field until the third evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your father misses me at all, then say, ‘David earnestly asked leave of me to run to Bethlehem his city, for there is a yearly sacrifice there for all the family.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If he says, ‘Good!’ it will be well with your servant, but if he is angry, then know that evil has been determined by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore deal kindly with your servant, for you have brought your servant into a sacred covenant with you. But if there is guilt in me, kill me yourself; why should you bring me to your father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said, “Far be it from you! If I knew that it was decided by my father that evil should come upon you, would I not tell you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Jonathan, “Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan replied to David, “Come, let us go out into the field.” So they both went out into the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to David, “By the Lord, the God of Israel! When I have sounded out my father, about this time tomorrow or on the third day, if he is well disposed toward David, shall I not then send and disclose it to you?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if my father intends to do you harm, the Lord do so to Jonathan and more also, if I do not disclose it to you and send you away, so that you may go in safety. May the Lord be with you, as he has been with my father.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I am still alive, show me the faithful love of the Lord, but if I die,
speaker: Narrator

text: never cut off your faithful love from my house, even if the Lord were to cut off every one of the enemies of David from the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, “May the Lord seek out the enemies of David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan made David swear again by his love for him, for he loved him as he loved his own life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to him, “Tomorrow is the new moon; you will be missed because your place will be empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day after tomorrow, you shall go a long way down; go to the place where you hid yourself earlier, and remain beside the stone there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will shoot three arrows to the side of it, as though I shot at a mark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will send the boy, saying, ‘Go, find the arrows.’ If I say to the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are on this side of you; collect them,’ then you are to come, for, as the Lord lives, it is safe for you and there is no danger.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I say to the young man, ‘Look, the arrows are beyond you,’ then go, for the Lord has sent you away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the matter about which you and I have spoken, the Lord be between you and me forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David hid himself in the field. When the new moon came, the king sat at the feast to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sat upon his seat, as at other times, upon the seat by the wall. Jonathan stood, while Abner sat by Saul’s side, but David’s place was empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul did not say anything that day, for he thought, “Something has befallen him; he is not clean; surely he is not clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the second day, the day after the new moon, David’s place was empty. And Saul said to his son Jonathan, “Why has the son of Jesse not come to the feast, either yesterday or today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered Saul, “David earnestly asked leave of me to go to Bethlehem;
speaker: Narrator

text: he said, ‘Let me go, for our family is holding a sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there. So now, if I have found favor in your sight, let me get away and see my brothers.’ For this reason he has not come to the king’s table.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul’s anger was kindled against Jonathan. He said to him, “You son of a rebellious woman! Do I not know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of your mother’s nakedness?
speaker: Narrator

text: For as long as the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, neither you nor your kingdom shall be established. Now send and bring him to me, for he shall surely die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan answered his father Saul, “Why should he be put to death? What has he done?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul threw his spear at him to strike him, so Jonathan knew that it was the decision of his father to put David to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan sprang up from the table in fierce anger and ate no food on the second day of the month, for he was grieved for David and because his father had disgraced him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning Jonathan went out into the field to the appointment with David, and with him was a little boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the boy, “Run and find the arrows that I shoot.” As the boy ran, he shot an arrow beyond him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the boy came to the place where Jonathan’s arrow had fallen, Jonathan called after the boy and said, “Is the arrow not beyond you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan called after the boy, “Hurry, be quick, do not linger.” So Jonathan’s boy gathered up the arrows and came to his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the boy knew nothing; only Jonathan and David knew the arrangement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy and said to him, “Go and carry them to the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the boy had gone, David rose from beside the stone heap and prostrated himself with his face to the ground. He bowed three times, and they kissed each other and wept with each other; David wept the more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, since both of us have sworn in the name of the Lord, saying, ‘The Lord shall be between me and you and between my descendants and your descendants forever.’ ” He got up and left, and Jonathan went into the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Nob to the priest Ahimelech. Ahimelech came trembling to meet David and said to him, “Why are you alone and no one with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to the priest Ahimelech, “The king has charged me with a matter and said to me, ‘No one must know anything of the matter about which I send you and with which I have charged you.’ I have made an appointment with the young men for such and such a place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, what have you at hand? Give me five loaves of bread or whatever is here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest answered David, “I have no ordinary bread at hand, only holy bread—provided that the young men have kept themselves from women.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David answered the priest, “Indeed, women have been kept from us as always when I go on an expedition; the vessels of the young men are holy even when it is a common journey; how much more today will their vessels be holy?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest gave him the holy bread, for there was no bread there except the bread of the Presence, which is removed from before the Lord, to be replaced by hot bread on the day it is taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a certain man of the servants of Saul was there that day, detained before the Lord; his name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of Saul’s shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ahimelech, “Is there no spear or sword here with you? I did not bring my sword or my weapons with me because the king’s business required haste.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest said, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the valley of Elah, is here wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod; if you will take that, take it, for there is none here except that one.” David said, “There is none like it; give it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David rose and fled that day from Saul; he went to King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The servants of Achish said to him, “Is this not David the king of the land? Did they not sing to one another of him in dances,
‘Saul has killed his thousands
    and David his ten thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David took these words to heart and was very much afraid of King Achish of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he changed his behavior before them; he pretended to be mad when in their presence. He scratched marks on the doors of the gate and let his spittle run down his beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish said to his servants, “Look, you see the man is mad; why then have you brought him to me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I lack madmen, that you have brought this fellow to play the madman in my presence? Shall this fellow come into my house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David left there and escaped to the cave of Adullam; when his brothers and all his father’s house heard of it, they went down there to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who was in distress, and everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was discontented gathered to him, and he became captain over them. Those who were with him numbered about four hundred.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went from there to Mizpeh of Moab. He said to the king of Moab, “Please let my father and mother come to you, until I know what God will do for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him all the time that David was in the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet Gad said to David, “Do not remain in the stronghold; leave and go into the land of Judah.” So David left and went into the forest of Hereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul heard that David and those who were with him had been located. Saul was sitting at Gibeah, under the tamarisk tree on the height, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his servants who stood around him, “Hear now, you Benjaminites; will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards? Will he make you all commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is that why all of you have conspired against me? No one discloses to me when my son makes a league with the son of Jesse; none of you is sorry for me or discloses to me that my son has stirred up my servant against me to lie in wait, as he is doing today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Doeg the Edomite, who was in charge of Saul’s servants, answered, “I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech son of Ahitub;
speaker: Narrator

text: he inquired of the Lord for him, gave him provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent for the priest Ahimelech son of Ahitub and for all his father’s house, the priests who were at Nob, and all of them came to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “Listen now, son of Ahitub.” He answered, “Here I am, my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to him, “Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, by giving him bread and a sword and by inquiring of God for him, so that he has risen against me to lie in wait, as he is doing today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimelech answered the king, “Who among all your servants is so faithful as David? He is the king’s son-in-law and is quick to do your bidding and is honored in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is today the first time that I have inquired of God for him? By no means! Do not let the king impute anything to his servant or to any member of my father’s house, for your servant has known nothing of all this, much or little.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the guard who stood around him, “Turn and kill the priests of the Lord, because their hand also is with David; they knew that he fled and did not disclose it to me.” But the servants of the king would not raise a hand to attack the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Doeg, “You, Doeg, turn and attack the priests.” Doeg the Edomite turned and attacked the priests; on that day he killed eighty-five who wore the linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nob, the city of the priests, he put to the sword; men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep, he put to the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of the sons of Ahimelech son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled after David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abiathar, “I knew on that day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would surely tell Saul. I am responsible for the lives of all your father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with me, and do not be afraid, for the one who seeks my life seeks your life; you will be safe with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now they told David, “The Philistines are fighting against Keilah and are robbing the threshing floors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I go and attack these Philistines?” The Lord said to David, “Go and attack the Philistines and save Keilah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David’s men said to him, “Look, we are afraid here in Judah; how much more then if we go to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David inquired of the Lord again. The Lord answered him, “Yes, go down to Keilah, for I will give the Philistines into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men went to Keilah, fought with the Philistines, brought away their livestock, and dealt them a heavy defeat. Thus David rescued the inhabitants of Keilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abiathar son of Ahimelech fled to David at Keilah, he came down with an ephod in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it was told Saul that David had come to Keilah. And Saul said, “God has given him into my hand, for he has shut himself in by entering a town that has gates and bars.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul summoned all the people to war, to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David learned that Saul was plotting evil against him, he said to the priest Abiathar, “Bring the ephod here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “O Lord, the God of Israel, your servant has heard that Saul seeks to come to Keilah, to destroy the city on my account.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, will Saul come down as your servant has heard? O Lord, the God of Israel, I beseech you, tell your servant.” The Lord said, “He will come down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “Will the men of Keilah surrender me and my men into the hand of Saul?” The Lord said, “They will surrender you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and his men, who were about six hundred, set out and left Keilah; they wandered wherever they could go. When Saul was told that David had escaped from Keilah, he gave up the expedition.
speaker: Narrator

text: David remained in the strongholds in the wilderness, in the hill country of the wilderness of Ziph. Saul sought him every day, but the Lord did not give him into his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh when he learned that Saul had come out to seek his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s son Jonathan set out and came to David at Horesh; there he strengthened his hand through the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Do not be afraid, for the hand of my father Saul shall not find you; you shall be king over Israel, and I shall be second to you; my father Saul also knows that this is so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two of them made a covenant before the Lord; David remained at Horesh, and Jonathan went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah and said, “David is hiding among us in the strongholds of Horesh, on the hill of Hachilah, which is south of Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O king, whenever you wish to come down, do so, and our part will be to surrender him into the king’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “May you be blessed by the Lord for showing me compassion!
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and make sure once more; find out exactly where he is and who has seen him there, for I am told that he is very cunning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look around and learn all the hiding places where he lurks and come back to me with sure information. Then I will go with you, and if he is in the land, I will search him out among all the thousands of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they set out and went to Ziph ahead of Saul.
David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the Arabah to the south of Jeshimon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and his men went to search for him. When David was told, he went down to the rock and stayed in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard that, he pursued David into the wilderness of Maon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul went on one side of the mountain and David and his men on the other side of the mountain. David was hurrying to get away from Saul, while Saul and his men were closing in on David and his men to capture them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a messenger came to Saul, saying, “Hurry and come, for the Philistines have made a raid on the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul stopped pursuing David and went against the Philistines; therefore that place was called the Rock of Escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: David then went up from there and lived in the strongholds of En-gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul returned from following the Philistines, he was told, “David is in the wilderness of En-gedi.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul took three thousand chosen men out of all Israel and went to look for David and his men in the direction of the Rocks of the Wild Goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to the sheepfolds beside the road, where there was a cave, and Saul went in to relieve himself. Now David and his men were sitting in the innermost parts of the cave.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of David said to him, “Here is the day of which the Lord said to you, ‘I will give your enemy into your hand, and you shall do to him as it seems good to you.’ ” Then David went and stealthily cut off a corner of Saul’s cloak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward David was stricken to the heart because he had cut off a corner of Saul’s cloak.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his men, “The Lord forbid that I should do this thing to my lord, the Lord’s anointed, to raise my hand against him, for he is the Lord’s anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David rebuked his men severely and did not permit them to attack Saul. Then Saul got up and left the cave and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward David also rose up and went out of the cave and called after Saul, “My lord the king!” When Saul looked behind him, David bowed with his face to the ground and did obeisance.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Why do you listen to the words of those who say, ‘David seeks to do you harm’?
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day your eyes have seen how the Lord gave you into my hand in the cave, and some urged me to kill you, but I spared you. I said, ‘I will not raise my hand against my lord, for he is the Lord’s anointed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: See, my father, see the corner of your cloak in my hand, for by the fact that I cut off the corner of your cloak and did not kill you, you may know for certain that there is no wrong or treason in my hands. I have not sinned against you, though you are hunting me to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord judge between me and you! May the Lord avenge me on you, but my hand shall not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the ancient proverb says, ‘Out of the wicked comes forth wickedness,’ but my hand shall not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against whom has the king of Israel come out? Whom do you pursue? A dead dog? A single flea?
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord, therefore, be judge and give sentence between me and you. May he see to it and plead my cause and vindicate me against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished speaking these words to Saul, Saul said, “Is this your voice, my son David?” Saul lifted up his voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to David, “You are more righteous than I, for you have repaid me good, whereas I have repaid you evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today you have explained how you have dealt well with me, in that you did not kill me when the Lord put me into your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who has ever found an enemy and sent the enemy safely away? So may the Lord reward you with good for what you have done to me this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know that you shall surely be king and that the kingdom of Israel shall be established in your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Swear to me, therefore, by the Lord that you will not cut off my descendants after me and that you will not wipe out my name from my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David swore this to Saul. Then Saul went home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Samuel died, and all Israel assembled and mourned for him. They buried him at his home in Ramah.
Then David got up and went down to the wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man in Maon whose property was in Carmel. The man was very rich; he had three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. He was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the name of the man was Nabal, and the name of his wife was Abigail. The woman was clever and beautiful, but the man was surly and mean; he was a Calebite.
speaker: Narrator

text: David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent ten young men, and David said to the young men, “Go up to Carmel, and go to Nabal, and greet him in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you shall salute him, ‘Peace be to you, and peace be to your house, and peace be to all that you have.
speaker: Narrator

text: I hear that you have shearers; now your shepherds have been with us, and we did them no harm, and they missed nothing all the time they were in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore let my young men find favor in your sight, for we have come on a feast day. Please give whatever you have at hand to your servants and to your son David.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s young men came, they said all this to Nabal in the name of David, and then they waited.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nabal answered David’s servants, “Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? There are many servants today who are breaking away from their masters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall I take my bread and my water and the meat that I have butchered for my shearers and give it to men who come from I do not know where?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s young men turned away and came back and told him all this.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to his men, “Every man strap on his sword!” And every one of them strapped on his sword; David also strapped on his sword, and about four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred remained with the baggage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “David sent messengers out of the wilderness to salute our master, and he shouted insults at them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the men were very good to us, and we suffered no harm, and we never missed anything when we were in the fields as long as we were with them;
speaker: Narrator

text: they were a wall to us both by night and by day, all the while we were with them keeping the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, know this and consider what you should do, for evil has been decided against our master and against all his house; he is so ill-natured that no one can speak to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abigail hurried and took two hundred loaves, two skins of wine, five sheep ready dressed, five measures of parched grain, one hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs. She loaded them on donkeys
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to her young men, “Go on ahead of me; I am coming after you.” But she did not tell her husband Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she rode on the donkey and came down under cover of the mountain, David and his men came down toward her, and she met them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had said, “Surely it was in vain that I protected all that this fellow has in the wilderness, so that nothing was missed of all that belonged to him, but he has returned me evil for good.
speaker: Narrator

text: God do so to David and more also if by morning I leave so much as one male of all who belong to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abigail saw David, she hurried and dismounted from the donkey and fell before David on her face, bowing to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: She fell at his feet and said, “Upon me alone, my lord, be the guilt; please let your servant speak in your ears and hear the words of your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord, do not take seriously this ill-natured fellow, Nabal, for as his name is, so is he; Nabal is his name, and folly is with him, but I, your servant, did not see the young men of my lord, whom you sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now then, my lord, as the Lord lives and as you yourself live, since the Lord has restrained you from bloodguilt and from taking vengeance with your own hand, now let your enemies and those who seek to do evil to my lord be like Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now let this present that your servant has brought to my lord be given to the young men who follow my lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please forgive the trespass of your servant, for the Lord will certainly make my lord a sure house, because my lord is fighting the battles of the Lord, and evil shall not be found in you so long as you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone should rise up to pursue you and to seek your life, the life of my lord shall be bound in the bundle of the living under the care of the Lord your God, but the lives of your enemies he shall sling out as from the hollow of a sling.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has done to my lord according to all the good that he has spoken concerning you and has appointed you prince over Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: my lord shall have no cause of grief or pangs of conscience for having shed blood without cause or for having saved himself. And when the Lord has dealt well with my lord, then remember your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abigail, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who sent you to meet me today!
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed be your good sense, and blessed be you, who kept me today from bloodguilt and from avenging myself by my own hand!
speaker: Narrator

text: For as surely as the Lord the God of Israel lives, who has restrained me from hurting you, unless you had hurried and come to meet me, truly by morning there would not have been left to Nabal so much as one male.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David received from her hand what she had brought him; he said to her, “Go up to your house in peace; see, I have heeded your voice, and I have granted your petition.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail came to Nabal; he was holding a feast in his house like the feast of a king. Nabal’s heart was merry within him, for he was very drunk, so she told him nothing at all until the morning light.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, when the wine had gone out of Nabal, his wife told him these things, and his heart died within him; he became like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: About ten days later the Lord struck Nabal, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Blessed be the Lord, who has judged the case of Nabal’s insult to me and has kept back his servant from evil; the Lord has returned the evildoing of Nabal upon his own head.” Then David sent word to Abigail to make her his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they said to her, “David has sent us to you to take you to him as his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She rose and bowed down, with her face to the ground, and said, “Your servant is a slave to wash the feet of the servants of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail got up hurriedly and rode away on a donkey; her five maids attended her. She went after the messengers of David and became his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel; both of them became his wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to Palti son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah, saying, “David is in hiding on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite Jeshimon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul rose and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, with three thousand chosen men of Israel, to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul encamped on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite Jeshimon, beside the road. But David remained in the wilderness. When he learned that Saul had come after him into the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent out spies and learned that Saul had indeed arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David set out and came to the place where Saul had encamped, and David saw the place where Saul lay, with Abner son of Ner, the commander of his army. Saul was lying within the encampment, while the army was encamped around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Ahimelech the Hittite and to Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, “Who will go down with me into the camp to Saul?” Abishai said, “I will go down with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and Abishai went to the army by night; there Saul lay sleeping within the encampment, with his spear stuck in the ground at his head, and Abner and the army lay around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai said to David, “God has given your enemy into your hand today; now, therefore, let me pin him to the ground with one stroke of the spear; I will not strike him twice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said to Abishai, “Do not destroy him, for who can raise his hand against the Lord’s anointed and be guiltless?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “As the Lord lives, the Lord will strike him down, or his day will come to die, or he will go down into battle and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord forbid that I should raise my hand against the Lord’s anointed, but now take the spear that is at his head and the water jar, and let us go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David took the spear that was at Saul’s head and the water jar, and they went away. No one saw it or knew it, nor did anyone awake, for they were all asleep, because a deep sleep from the Lord had fallen upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David went over to the other side and stood on top of a hill far away, with a great distance between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: David called to the army and to Abner son of Ner, saying, “Abner! Will you not answer?” Then Abner replied, “Who are you who calls to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abner, “Are you not a man? Who is like you in Israel? Why then have you not kept watch over your lord the king? For one of the people came in to destroy your lord the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: This thing that you have done is not good. As the Lord lives, you deserve to die because you have not kept watch over your lord, the Lord’s anointed. See now, where is the king’s spear or the water jar that was at his head?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul recognized David’s voice and said, “Is this your voice, my son David?” David said, “It is my voice, my lord, O king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he added, “Why does my lord pursue his servant? For what have I done? What guilt is on my hands?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, let my lord the king hear the words of his servant. If it is the Lord who has stirred you up against me, may he accept an offering, but if it is mortals, may they be cursed before the Lord, for they have driven me out today from my share in the heritage of the Lord, saying, ‘Go, serve other gods.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, do not let my blood fall to the ground away from the presence of the Lord, for the king of Israel has come out to seek a single flea, like one who hunts a partridge in the mountains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “I have done wrong; come back, my son David, for I will never harm you again, because my life was precious in your sight today; I have been a fool and have made a great mistake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David replied, “Here is the spear, O king! Let one of the young men come over and get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord rewards everyone for his righteousness and his faithfulness, for the Lord gave you into my hand today, but I would not raise my hand against the Lord’s anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: As your life was precious today in my sight, so may my life be precious in the sight of the Lord, and may he rescue me from all tribulation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to David, “Blessed be you, my son David! You will do many things and will succeed in them.” So David went his way, and Saul returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said in his heart, “I shall certainly perish one day by the hand of Saul; there is nothing better for me than to escape to the land of the Philistines; then Saul will despair of seeking me any longer within the borders of Israel, and I shall escape out of his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out and went over, he and the six hundred men who were with him, to King Achish son of Maoch of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed with Achish at Gath, he and his troops, every man with his household, and David with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail of Carmel, Nabal’s widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he no longer sought for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Achish, “If I have found favor in your sight, let a place be given me in one of the country towns so that I may live there, for why should your servant live in the royal city with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that day Achish gave him Ziklag; therefore Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of time that David lived in the country of the Philistines was one year and four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David and his men went up and made raids on the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites, for these were the landed settlements from Telam on the way to Shur and on to the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: David struck the land, leaving neither man nor woman alive, but took away the sheep, the oxen, the donkeys, the camels, and the clothing and came back to Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Achish asked, “Against whom have you made a raid today?” David would say, “Against the Negeb of Judah,” or “Against the Negeb of the Jerahmeelites,” or “Against the Negeb of the Kenites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David left neither man nor woman alive to be brought back to Gath, thinking, “They might tell about us and say, ‘David has done so and so.’ ” Such was his practice all the time he lived in the country of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish trusted David, thinking, “He has made himself utterly abhorrent to his people Israel; therefore he shall always be my servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Philistines gathered their forces for war, to fight against Israel. Achish said to David, “You know, of course, that you and your men are to go out with me in the army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Achish, “Very well, then you shall know what your servant can do.” Achish said to David, “Very well, I will make you my bodyguard for life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel had died, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in Ramah, his own city. Saul had expelled the mediums and the wizards from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled and came and encamped at Shunem. Saul gathered all Israel, and they encamped at Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw the army of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul inquired of the Lord, the Lord did not answer him, not by dreams or by Urim or by prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to his servants, “Seek out for me a woman who is a medium, so that I may go to her and inquire of her.” His servants said to him, “There is a medium at Endor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul disguised himself and put on other clothes and went there, he and two men with him. They came to the woman by night. And he said, “Consult a spirit for me, and bring up for me the one whom I name to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said to him, “Surely you know what Saul has done, how he has cut off the mediums and the wizards from the land. Why then are you laying a snare for my life to bring about my death?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul swore to her by the Lord, “As the Lord lives, no punishment shall come upon you for this thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman said, “Whom shall I bring up for you?” He answered, “Bring up Samuel for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice, and the woman said to Saul, “Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to her, “Have no fear; what do you see?” The woman said to Saul, “I see a divine being coming up out of the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “What is his appearance?” She said, “An old man is coming up; he is wrapped in a robe.” So Saul knew that it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground and did obeisance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?” Saul answered, “I am in great distress, for the Philistines are warring against me, and God has turned away from me and answers me no more, either by prophets or by dreams, so I have summoned you to tell me what I should do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Why then do you ask me, since the Lord has turned from you and become your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has done to you just as he spoke by me, for the Lord has torn the kingdom out of your hand and given it to your neighbor, David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you did not obey the voice of the Lord and did not carry out his fierce wrath against Amalek, therefore the Lord has done this thing to you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Lord will give Israel along with you into the hands of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons shall be with me; the Lord will also give the army of Israel into the hands of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately Saul fell full length on the ground filled with fear because of the words of Samuel, and there was no strength in him, for he had eaten nothing all day and all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman came to Saul, and when she saw that he was terrified, she said to him, “Your servant has listened to you; I have taken my life in my hand and have listened to what you have said to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, you also listen to your servant; let me set a morsel of bread before you. Eat, that you may have strength when you go on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He refused and said, “I will not eat.” But his servants, together with the woman, urged him, and he listened to their words. So he got up from the ground and sat on the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the woman had a fatted calf in the house. She quickly slaughtered it, and she took flour, kneaded it, and baked unleavened cakes.
speaker: Narrator

text: She put them before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they rose and went away that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines gathered all their forces at Aphek, while the Israelites were encamped by the spring that is in Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the lords of the Philistines were passing on by hundreds and by thousands and David and his men were passing on in the rear with Achish,
speaker: Narrator

text: the commanders of the Philistines said, “What are these Hebrews doing here?” Achish said to the commanders of the Philistines, “Is this not David, the servant of King Saul of Israel, who has been with me now for days and years? Since he deserted to me I have found no fault in him to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the commanders of the Philistines were angry with him, and the commanders of the Philistines said to him, “Send the man back, so that he may return to the place that you have assigned to him; he shall not go down with us to battle, or else he may become an adversary to us in the battle. For how could this fellow reconcile himself to his lord? Would it not be with the heads of the men here?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this not David, of whom they sing to one another in dances,
‘Saul has killed his thousands
    and David his ten thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Achish called David and said to him, “As the Lord lives, you have been honest, and to me it seems right that you should march out and in with me in the campaign, for I have found nothing wrong in you from the day of your coming to me until today. Nevertheless, the lords do not approve of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go back now, and go peaceably; do nothing to displease the lords of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Achish, “But what have I done? What have you found in your servant from the day I entered your service until now, that I should not go and fight against the enemies of my lord the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish replied to David, “I know that you are as blameless in my sight as an angel of God; nevertheless, the commanders of the Philistines have said, ‘He shall not go up with us to the battle.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, rise early in the morning, you and the servants of your lord who came with you, and go to the place that I appointed for you. As for the evil report, do not take it to heart, for you have done well before me. Start early in the morning, and leave as soon as you have light.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out with his men early in the morning, to return to the land of the Philistines. But the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had made a raid on the Negeb and on Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag, burned it down,
speaker: Narrator

text: and taken captive the women and all who were in it, both small and great; they killed none of them but carried them off and went their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David and his men came to the city, they found it burned down and their wives and sons and daughters taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and the people who were with him raised their voices and wept until they had no more strength to weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s two wives also had been taken captive, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was in great danger, for the people spoke of stoning him because all the people were bitter in spirit for their sons and daughters. But David strengthened himself in the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to the priest Abiathar son of Ahimelech, “Bring me the ephod.” So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I pursue this band? Shall I overtake them?” He answered him, “Pursue, for you shall surely overtake and shall surely rescue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out, he and the six hundred men who were with him. They came to the Wadi Besor, where those stayed who were left behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David went on with the pursuit, he and four hundred men; two hundred stayed behind, too exhausted to cross the Wadi Besor.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the open country they found an Egyptian and brought him to David. They gave him bread, and he ate; they gave him water to drink;
speaker: Narrator

text: they also gave him a piece of fig cake and two clusters of raisins. When he had eaten, his spirit revived, for he had not eaten bread or drunk water for three days and three nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to him, “To whom do you belong? Where are you from?” He said, “I am a young man of Egypt, servant to an Amalekite. My master left me behind because I fell sick three days ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: We had made a raid on the Negeb of the Cherethites and on that which belongs to Judah and on the Negeb of Caleb, and we burned Ziklag down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “Will you take me down to this raiding party?” He said, “Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will take you down to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had taken him down, they were spread out all over the ground, eating and drinking and dancing, because of the great amount of spoil they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David attacked them from twilight until the evening of the next day. Not one of them escaped, except four hundred young men, who mounted camels and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: David recovered all that the Amalekites had taken, and David rescued his two wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nothing was missing, whether small or great, sons or daughters, spoil or anything that had been taken; David brought back everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also captured all the flocks and herds, which were driven ahead of the other cattle; people said, “This is David’s spoil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow David and who had been left at the Wadi Besor. They went out to meet David and to meet the people who were with him. When David drew near to the people, he saluted them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the corrupt and worthless fellows among the men who had gone with David said, “Because they did not go with us, we will not give them any of the spoil that we have recovered, except that each man may take his wife and children and leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said, “You shall not do so, my brothers, with what the Lord has given us; he has preserved us and handed over to us the raiding party that attacked us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who would listen to you in this matter? For the share of the one who goes down into the battle shall be the same as the share of the one who stays by the baggage; they shall share alike.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From that day forward he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel; it continues to the present day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Ziklag, he sent part of the spoil to his friends, the elders of Judah, saying, “Here is a present for you from the spoil of the enemies of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was for those in Bethel, in Ramoth of the Negeb, in Jattir,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Aroer, in Siphmoth, in Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Racal, in the towns of the Jerahmeelites, in the towns of the Kenites,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hormah, in Bor-ashan, in Athach,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hebron, all the places where David and his men had roamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines fought against Israel, and the men of Israel fled before the Philistines, and many fell on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines overtook Saul and his sons, and the Philistines killed Jonathan and Abinadab and Malchishua, the sons of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle pressed hard on Saul, and the archers found him, and he was badly wounded by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and thrust me through with it, so that these uncircumcised may not come and thrust me through and make sport of me.” But his armor-bearer was unwilling, for he was terrified. So Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul and his three sons and his armor-bearer and all his men died together on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel who were on the other side of the valley and those beyond the Jordan saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they forsook their towns and fled, and the Philistines came and occupied them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the dead, they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut off his head, stripped off his armor, and sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to carry the good news to the houses of their idols and to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put his armor in the temple of Astarte, and they fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: all the valiant men set out, traveled all night long, and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan. They came to Jabesh and burned them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh and fasted seven days.
speaker: Narrator
